reviews.review: 2 boring hours followed by an alright ending.

The iconic Star Wars humor was spot on, and I think I liked it a lot because of its themes of mercy, love, and friendship. It also had a lot of traditional Star Wars elements like unlikely good guys defeating the powerful evil and appreciated the love story too! I hate when movies eliminate any romance and this has it!  I'm also glad they kept the cool mind bending between Rey and Kylo. The beginning was a bit fix it and exposition heavy to tie in the second movie but it wasn't awful. Also I loved getting backstory for Poe and Finn more. I also liked Rey's identity reveal because it was unexpected and gave her more depth. I thought this movie showed her as more dynamic and flawed sometimes which made her more real. I used to slightly dislike her due to her being automatically good at everything. My fav of the trilogy!
The forced inclusion of one of the old characters
With all the negative reviews, I went in with low expectations. But it turned out pretty good.

It was a good, solid movie closing out the stories of the last 42 years.  Don’t know why anyone would expect this movie to “move the story forward” or expand the universe.  It’s an ending, closure on the stories of those whom we started with.  Would I have done some things differently?  Yes, but I enjoyed it and will see it again.

Abrams to blame for overstuffed, hyperfast mess. Too many uneccessary characters and scenes that flood the senses with few breaks until the final chapter. It ends well but that doesn't erase the frantic ruckus Abrmas put us through. Easily the worst Star Wars movie.

The performances by Daisy Ridley and Adam Driver are absolutely brilliant.
Sadly, the Filmmaking team was burdened not just with the bizarre plot twists from The Last Jedi, but tragically with the absence of Carrie Fisher and the urgent need to find a way to weave their story around her unused footage from the first two films in the trilogy to complete her story arc.  That said, the fan service does distract a bit, but the production team did an outstanding job of executing the finale.  However the decision to dig up the Emperor and build the ending around him is suspect at best.  If the management team had established a clear arc for the trilogy before hand it would have served the franchise so much better than this "create the best recipe from these peculiar ingredients" method they found themselves burdened with at the beginning of this films creation. That said, the light saber battles, the flying sequences, the scope of the finale are so well executed that the performances by the core leads are elevated to an epic finale. This trilogy, though far from perfect, had the task of transitioning from the story of Luke, Leia, Han and Chewie to the story of Rey, Finn and Poe. The former cast had to meet their end in order to finalize the transition and that was where they had to begin. I applaud their efforts and appreciate the challenges they faced. I am looking forward to watching The Rise of Skywalker again next week, but am thankful for the team that created this trilogy. It would have been a shame if the last Star Wars film ever made was Revenge of the Sith.
Long live Star Wars and May the Force be With You.
This is a disgrace to the star wars lore.
too many action scenes, not enough story development
A bit OTT in places, but a creative, dramatic and satisfying end to it all.
